title: Research project would study moose
text:
Research project would study moose DAVE HENDERSON, Correspondent 3:22 p.m. EDT October 17, 2015 Male Moose 3 CONNECT 3 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE 
Cornell University’s Cooperative Fish and Wildlife Research Unit, the Department of Environmental Conservation, the SUNY College of Environmental Science and Forestry, and the Wildlife Conservation Society’s Adirondack Program are conducting a multi-year research project to obtain information on the status of New York’s moose population. 
The study is designed to determine the factors that influence moose survival and reproductive rate. The goal of the Adirondack moose study is to gather data that will be used to create a moose management plan. 
Last February, 12 moose were captured in the Adirondacks, fitted with GPS radio collars and released. Their movements continue to be tracked remotely. Of the nine cows that were collared, seven had calves, and two of those had twins. 
The study is also seeking information from the public regarding moose sightings to provide data. If you sight a moose, please report it to the DEC by calling the Region 5 Wildlife office at (518) 897-1291 or by completing and submitting the electronic reporting form. A link to the form can be found at the bottom of the DEC Moose web page. 
Hibernating bats 
The state is urging the public to avoid cave and mine sites that serve as homes for bat hibernations. 
Human disturbances are seen as harmful to the state's bat population since the arrival of the disease known as white-nose syndrome, which has killed more than 90 percent of bats at most hibernation sites in the state. 
Anyone encountering hibernating bats while underground should leave the area as quickly and quietly as possible. 
Experts believe that when bats are disturbed during hibernation periods, it forces them to raise their body temperatures, which causes their fat reserves to be depleted. This affects their energy levels and places the bats in a comprised state, which can often lead to death. 
For more information about white-nose syndrome and what you can do to help see: White-nose Syndrome website (link leaves DEC at www.dec.ny.gov.) 
Dave Henderson's outdoors columns appear in the Press & Sun-Bulletin on Thursday and his Field Notes columns on Sunday. Write to him at Henderson Outdoors (www.HendersonOutdoors.com), 202 Prospect St, Endicott NY 13760 or via e-mail at dddhender@aol.com. 3 CONNECT 3 TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE Read or Share this story: http://press.sn/1LAspFH TOP VIDEOS
